clinical_study.official_title: Monocentric, Randomized, Prospective Study to Compare Endocardiac Radio Frequency Ablation and Cryo Ablation of the Left Atrium During an Open Chest Mitral Valve Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: Monocentric, prospective, randomized trial of cardiac surgical arrhythmia using endocardial radiofrequency atrial ablation compared with a cryo ablation system in the setting of cardiac surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: Regular, rhythmic monitoring (24-hour Holter ECG, 5 and 28 days, 3 and 6 months po) of patients after cardiac surgery on the mitral valve with atrial ablation for paroxysmal, persistent, and permanent atrial fibrillation with regard to the presence or stability of sinus rhythm.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: monocentric, 1:1 randomized (cryo ablation vs. radiofrequency ablation), open-label, parallel, registry

primary_outcome.measure: number of patients with stabil sinus rhythm 6 month after ablation
primary_outcome.description: number of patients with stabil sinus rhythm 6 month after ablation

arm_group.description: cryo ablation of left atrium during mitral valve open chest intervention
radio frequency ablation of left atrium during mitral valve open chest intervention

intervention.intervention_name: ablation of left atrium during mitral valve open chest intervention
intervention.description: open chest mitral valve surgery (reconstruction or replacement) with additional ablation of left atrium by cryo or radio frequency method

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients ≥ 18 years
- Present, written informed consent from the patient
- paroxysmal, persistent, or permanent atrial fibrillation not longer than 10 years according to guidelines (ACC, AHA, ESC)
- planned cardiac surgery on the mitral valve
- ECHO parameters : LA size a.p. ≤ 55mm
Exclusion Criteria:
- permanent atrial fibrillation longer than 10 years
- ECHO parameters : LA size a.p. > 55mm
- pregnancy
- life expectancy < 12 months
- lack of cognitive or mental capacity to participate in the study
- Patients who are to be included in another clinical (interventional) study at the same time or who are already participating in such a study
